text: And these are the years of the life of Ishmael, an hundred  and thirty  and seven years: and he gave up the ghost and died; and was gathered unto his people.
text_kjv: And these are the years of the life of Ishmael, an hundred  and thirty  and seven years: and he gave up the ghost and died; and was gathered unto his people.
text_niv: Altogether, Ishmael lived a hundred and thirty-seven years. He breathed his last and died, and he was gathered to his people.
text_esv: (These are the years of the life of Ishmael: 137 years. He breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his people.)
text_nlt: Ishmael lived for 137 years. Then he breathed his last and joined his ancestors in death.
text_msg: Ishmael lived 137 years. When he breathed his last and died he was buried with his family.
text_nasb: These are the years of the life of Ishmael, one hundred and thirty-seven years; and he breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his people.
context: Genesis 25:17 records the death of Ishmael at the age of 137. Understanding the historical context requires acknowledging the significance of lineage and lifespan in ancient Near Eastern cultures. Lifespans were often symbolic, indicating divine favor or disfavor. A long life, like Ishmael's, was generally seen as a blessing. The phrase 'gathered unto his people' is a euphemism for death, implying a return to the ancestral realm or community. Ishmael was Abraham's firstborn son, born to Hagar, Sarah's handmaid. While not the son of the covenant (Isaac was), Ishmael still received a blessing from God, promised to father twelve princes and a great nation (Genesis 17:20). These 'princes' are generally understood to be the heads of various Arab tribes. The geographical area inhabited by Ishmael's descendants stretched across the Arabian Peninsula. His sons are listed in Genesis 25:12-16, providing a tribal map of the northern Arabian tribes. Their names offer glimpses into their culture and perhaps even their religious beliefs. Understanding that Genesis was written to a specific audience (the Israelites) is crucial. It presents Ishmael as distinct from the line of promise (Isaac), but acknowledges his divinely ordained destiny as the progenitor of a large and significant people. The narrative aims to establish Israel's unique covenant relationship with God while respecting Ishmael's place in the broader Abrahamic family. The mention of Ishmael's death provides closure to his narrative arc within the Genesis account, further solidifying Isaac's lineage as the chosen line through which God's promises will be fulfilled.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 25:17, while seemingly simple, carries profound weight. It underscores the sovereignty of God, particularly in the fulfillment of his promises. God had promised Abraham that Ishmael would be the father of twelve princes and a great nation, and this verse, coupled with the preceding genealogy, demonstrates the faithfulness of God to even his secondary promises. The statement 'he gave up the ghost and died' signifies the end of Ishmael's earthly journey and a transition to the afterlife, as understood in the ancient Hebrew context. The phrase 'gathered unto his people' is a common expression in the Old Testament, suggesting a continuation of existence in some form beyond physical death, joining ancestors in Sheol. It acknowledges the mortality of all men, regardless of their lineage or God's specific promises to them. Even Ishmael, blessed with a long life and numerous descendants, ultimately faced death. This highlights the limitations of earthly blessings and the importance of seeking eternal life. Furthermore, the verse implicitly contrasts Ishmael's fate with the covenant promises given to Isaac. While Ishmael's lineage prospers materially, the covenant promises of spiritual blessing and redemption are specifically reserved for Isaac and his descendants. The passing of Ishmael reinforces the importance of understanding God's specific calling and purposes for each individual and nation. It's a reminder that God's blessings are diverse, and while material prosperity is a gift, it's not the ultimate measure of God's favor. Ultimately, this verse points to the need for a deeper understanding of God's plan of salvation through Jesus Christ, which transcends earthly lineages and promises.
application: Genesis 25:17, recounting Ishmael's death, offers several practical applications for modern believers. First, it highlights the brevity of life. Ishmael, though living 137 years, eventually faced death, reminding us that our time on earth is finite. This should motivate us to make the most of each day, living intentionally and purposefully for God's glory. We should prioritize what truly matters: our relationship with God, our service to others, and the pursuit of eternal values. Second, it underscores the importance of acknowledging and respecting those who are different from us. Ishmael was not the son of the covenant, yet he was still blessed by God. We should extend grace and compassion to those who hold different beliefs or come from different backgrounds, recognizing that God's love encompasses all people. Third, it challenges us to re-evaluate our definition of success. Ishmael was the father of a great nation, achieving worldly success. However, true success, according to biblical standards, lies in faithfulness to God's calling and obedience to His word. We must guard against prioritizing worldly achievements over spiritual growth and eternal rewards. Fourth, it calls us to consider our legacy. What kind of impact will we leave on the world? Will it be a legacy of faith, love, and service, or one of self-centeredness and materialism? We should strive to live lives that honor God and inspire others to follow Him. Finally, the verse reminds us to reflect on our own mortality and prepare for eternity. Are we ready to meet God? Have we accepted Jesus Christ as our Lord and Savior? It's never too late to turn to God and seek His forgiveness and grace. We should live each day with eternity in mind, knowing that one day we, too, will 'give up the ghost and die' and be 'gathered unto our people'.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the reminder that life is fleeting, as demonstrated by the passing of Ishmael. Help us to number our days and to live with wisdom and purpose, knowing that our time on earth is limited. Forgive us for the times we have wasted our time on trivial pursuits and neglected our relationship with you. Grant us the grace to prioritize what truly matters: seeking your kingdom and serving others in your name. Help us to be mindful of our mortality and to prepare our hearts for eternity. Give us the courage to share the gospel with those who have not yet heard, so that they too may find salvation in Jesus Christ. Teach us to love and respect those who are different from us, recognizing that every person is created in your image. May our lives be a testament to your love and grace, so that when we come to the end of our earthly journey, we may be welcomed into your eternal presence. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: The phrase 'gathered unto his people' is an ancient Hebrew idiom referring to death and burial. It suggests a return to the ancestral lineage or a communal afterlife, rather than a strict description of a physical burial in a specific location. It implies a connection to the spiritual realm of one's ancestors.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does 'gathered unto his people' mean?

faqs.answer: While Ishmael was not the son of the covenant promise (Isaac was), God still blessed him. His death fulfills the promise of progeny and a great nation, albeit distinct from the covenant line through which salvation would come. It highlights God's faithfulness to all his promises.
faqs.question: Q2: How does Ishmael's death connect to the Abrahamic covenant?

faqs.answer: The specific age underscores the fulfillment of God's promise of a long life for Ishmael (Genesis 17:20). Lifespans were significant in ancient times, often seen as indicative of God's favor or disfavor. A long life was a sign of blessing and divine provision.
faqs.question: Q3: Why is the age of Ishmael recorded?

faqs.answer: Ishmael's 'people' refer to his descendants, the tribes of northern Arabia. The phrase implies a shared ancestry and a common cultural identity. They are the nations that sprung from his twelve sons listed in Genesis 25:12-16.
faqs.question: Q4: Who are Ishmael's 'people' mentioned in the verse?

faqs.answer: The main point is to provide closure to Ishmael's story within the Genesis narrative and to solidify Isaac's lineage as the chosen line of the covenant promise. It shows that God keeps his promises even to those outside the direct covenant line while reinforcing the importance of Isaac's line.
